channel.title: [317] A basic sound system (weapon sounds)
channel.description:
[b]Base:[/b] Delta [b]Difficulty[/b]: 2/10
Video of sounds: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oD_qFfiDpQU&feature=player_detailpage
So, many people on msn asked me how I handled my sounds, here it is.
[size=14pt]PLEASE NOTE I AM NOT GIVING YOU THE CLIENT SIDED CODES[/size]
In this tutorial I'll be giving you the proper methods needed to play a sound, and also a weapon sound system.
First off you'll need this method:
[code=java] public void frame174(int sound, int vol, int delay) { outStream.createFrame(174); outStream.writeWord(sound); outStream.writeByte(vol); outStream.writeWord(delay); updateRequired = true; appearanceUpdateRequired = true; } [/code]
[i]This method is the actual frame that plays the sound, it's known as frame 174.[/i]
It's usage is this:
[code=java] frame174(soundId, volume, delay); [/code]
The parameters are self explanatory, I just needed to show you people who don't read params. Adding sounds are very easy after that, you simply call this method whenever you want a sound played..
So now that you know how to create a sound, here's a basic system for you..
[code=java] package org.model.sounds;
public class WeaponSounds {
public int getWeaponSound(int weapon) { switch (weapon) {
default: return 399; // plays sound 399 if weapon is not defined above } } } [/code]
This is basically the same concept as handling weapon animations, just sounds. So all you have to do is add a weapon underneath the switch, along with the sound id it's supposed to return.
[code=java] case WEAPON: return SOUND; [/code]
You'll also need to add these methods in your client class so you do not have to make the methods static:
[code=java] public WeaponSounds getWepSound() { return weaponSounds; }
public WeaponSounds weaponSounds = new WeaponSounds(); [/code]
Next what we have to do is make sure the sound is actually played when a user attacks;
Underneath your attackPlayer() method, add this (preferably above where your weapon animation starts):
[code=java] if (!specOn) { frame174( getWepSound().getWeaponSound( playerEquipment[playerWeapon]), 1, 000); } [/code] [i]This is stating that if a user is not using a special, and is attacking with a weapon identified in the WeaponSounds class, it'll return it with the sound id it's set too.[/i]
[b]You can also copy this weapon system and create a defence system, using the player's shield instead of their weapon.[/b]
That's about it, but you can do a lot with sounds.
Jad magic attack: [code=java] frame174(1749, 1, 5); frame174(1014, 1, 70); frame174(1021, 1, 115); [/code]
Sound list foar u [code] These are my found lists: 190 - entangle 191 - entangle splash 192 - something splash? 193 - 192 succeed 194 - another succeed of 192 200 - telekenitic grab 201 - some kind of teleport 202 - teleport 203 - some enchant 204 - superheat? 205 - another enchant 206 - faster 205 207 - another enchant 208 - 3 stutters then enchant 209 - 2 stutters then enchant 210 - 208 then fire sound 211 - 208 then bouncey sound? 212 - another enchant 213 - nice sound then fire 214 - 213 but kind of teleport sound 215 - 214 216 - 214 then fire 217 - superheat 218 - superheat failure? 219 - teleother? 220 - entangle? 221 - failure of some sort 222 - cool sound 223 - high alch :D 224 - low alch :D 225 - enfeeble? 226 - failure 227 - kawa 228 - fall on something hot? 229 - sharp sound 230 - equip something?? :O! 231 - down sound then fire 232 - spade 233 - bang 234 - pop 235 - cooking 236 - birds 237 - water? 238 - bang 239 - water then ahh? 240 - fire 241 - bubbles 242 - more bubbles 243 - 2500 - home tele 1080 - whip attack sound 1081 - whip special sound 367 - some kind of bow fire 463 - armour block 436 - inproved refexes 434 - superhuman str 433 - protect item 437 - 0 prayer 435 - pray off 438 - protect from magic 439 - steel skin 440 - incredible reflexes 441 - ultimate str 442 - pray fill 443 - some pray thing idk what one 444 - protect from range 445 - pray maybe? 446 - chick skin 447 - not high enuf pray 448 - clarity of thought 449 - rock skin 450 - burst of str 451 - mage boost 452 - snowball throw 455 - cross wildy ditch 069 - hitted 070 - npc man ded 071 - npc girl ded 072 - hitted sound 161 : strike cast sound 240 : cooking i think sound 223: alching - high sound 224 : alching - low sound 370 : arrow sound 816 : getting hit sound 818: getting hit (female) and so on till 823 lol sound 986 : blood burst? item.title: [317] A basic sound system (weapon sounds)
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

T4_:

It does suck. All it is is crafting a packet and handling what sounds correspond to what event (in a really shit way).

Exactly. Between players, nothing about the data changes. So, there only needs to be one instance of a SoundManager, not creating on per player (biggest annoyance with Hyperion-based servers). And since there is only one method, you could even just put it in the PacketBuilder class because, well, that’s all this is doing. Creating a packet, and sending it.

Read full topic

item.title: [317] A basic sound system (weapon sounds)
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Why the fuck don’t you want the method static?

public static void playSound(final Client client, final int id,
    final int volume, final int delay) throws IllegalArgumentException {
    if (client == null) {
        throw new IllegalArgumentException("Client cannot be null");
    }
    if (id < 0) {
        throw new IllegalArgumentException(
            "id must be non-negative integer: " + id);
    }
    if (volume < 0) {
        throw new IllegalArgumentException(
            "volume must be non-negative integer: " + volume);
    }
    if (delay < 0) {
        throw new IllegalArgumentException(
            "delay must be non-negative integer: " + delay);
    }
    final PacketBuilder builder = new PacketBuilder(6);
    builder.putByte(174).putShort(id).putByte(volume).putShort(delay);
    client.sendPacket(builder.build());
}

Just an example. There is no reason why it shouldn’t be static.

Read full topic

item.title: [317] A basic sound system (weapon sounds)
item.dc:creator: @kingdomkey01 kingdomkey01
item.description:
@kingdomkey01 wrote:

Base: Delta
Difficulty: 2/10

Video of sounds:

So, many people on msn asked me how I handled my sounds, here it is.

[size=14pt]PLEASE NOTE I AM NOT GIVING YOU THE CLIENT SIDED CODES[/size]

In this tutorial I’ll be giving you the proper methods needed to play a sound, and also a weapon sound system.

First off you’ll need this method:

	public void frame174(int sound, int vol, int delay) {
		outStream.createFrame(174);
		outStream.writeWord(sound);
		outStream.writeByte(vol);
		outStream.writeWord(delay);
		updateRequired = true;
		appearanceUpdateRequired = true;
	}

This method is the actual frame that plays the sound, it’s known as frame 174.

It’s usage is this:

frame174(soundId, volume, delay);

The parameters are self explanatory, I just needed to show you people who don’t read params. Adding sounds are very easy after that, you simply call this method whenever you want a sound played…

So now that you know how to create a sound, here’s a basic system for you…

package org.model.sounds;

public class WeaponSounds {

	public int getWeaponSound(int weapon) {
		switch (weapon) {

		default:
			return 399; // plays sound 399 if weapon is not defined above
		}
	}
}

This is basically the same concept as handling weapon animations, just sounds. So all you have to do is add a weapon underneath the switch, along with the sound id it’s supposed to return.

case WEAPON:
     return SOUND;

You’ll also need to add these methods in your client class so you do not have to make the methods static:

	public WeaponSounds getWepSound() {
		return weaponSounds;
	}

	public WeaponSounds weaponSounds = new WeaponSounds();

Next what we have to do is make sure the sound is actually played when a user attacks;

Underneath your attackPlayer() method, add this (preferably above where your weapon animation starts):

					if (!specOn) {
						frame174(
								getWepSound().getWeaponSound(
										playerEquipment[playerWeapon]), 1, 000);
					}

This is stating that if a user is not using a special, and is attacking with a weapon identified in the WeaponSounds class, it’ll return it with the sound id it’s set too.

You can also copy this weapon system and create a defence system, using the player’s shield instead of their weapon.

That’s about it, but you can do a lot with sounds.

Jad magic attack:

	frame174(1749, 1, 5);
	frame174(1014, 1, 70);
	frame174(1021, 1, 115);
